explanation:
num_threads: the global variable read and written by get_num_threads. Need its declaration (type, linkage, volatile/atomic qualifiers) and any invariants to determine whether it can act as or be modified like a for-loop counter elsewhere and whether its modification here could interact with loop rules.

get_cpu_core_count: direct callee. Its implementation may contain for-loops (or modify globals) whose body/behaviour must be examined when checking for-loop well-formedness in code that calls it.

get_process_cpu_core_count: direct callee. Same reason as get_cpu_core_count — its implementation may contain for-loops or produce side-effects relevant to loop-counter rules.

detect_cpu_core_count: callee of get_cpu_core_count. Inspecting this symbol is required because get_cpu_core_count may delegate loop-bearing logic to it; any for-loops there must be checked against the MISRA rule and against interactions with callers.

detect_process_cpu_core_count: callee of get_process_cpu_core_count. Same rationale as detect_cpu_core_count — necessary to examine any for-loops and side-effects in the transitive call chain.

printf: used in get_num_threads. Although unlikely to affect loop counters, it is a side-effecting library function; include its prototype/semantics to be certain it does not modify objects that could be used as loop counters in any for-loops encountered during analysis.
